title: 109_s4121
content: The curr_chunk is a section titled "TREATMENT OF LIABILITY FOR CERTAIN MULTIPLE EMPLOYER PLANS." The curr_chunk discusses the liability determination for an applicable pension plan based on whether an eligible employer elects subsection (b) or not. If the election is made, liability is determined under subsection (b) within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The applicable pension plan's liability is determined under subsection (c). If an eligible employer elects within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the plan's assets and liabilities are spun off to an eligible spunoff plan, and the employer's liability is determined by reference to the spunoff plan. The employer's liability for the applicable pension plan is determined by reference to the eligible spunoff plan. This liability is in lieu of any other liability to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. Liability of employers electing spinoff: The Pension Protection Act of 2006 amendments do not apply to eligible spunoff plans until they cease to be eligible or January 1, 2017. The employer is responsible for ongoing funding liability until then. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 amendments do not apply to eligible spunoff plans until they cease to be eligible or January 1, 2017. The employer maintaining the plan is liable for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan as per ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 amendments do not apply to eligible spunoff plans until they cease to be eligible or January 1, 2017. The employer is liable for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan under ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code, subject to specific conditions. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 amendments do not apply to eligible spunoff plans until they cease to be eligible or January 1, 2017. The employer is liable for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan under ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code, subject to specific conditions related to the pension plan. Interest rates are determined according to specific sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 amendments do not apply to eligible spunoff plans until after December 31, 2007. Interest rates are determined under specific sections of ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 amendments apply to eligible spunoff plans after December 31, 2007. The third segment rate determined under specific sections of ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code shall be used instead of the usual interest rate. If an eligible spunoff plan terminates before December 31, 2010, the employer's liability is affected. If an eligible spunoff plan terminates before December 31, 2010, the employer's liability shall be determined in accordance with specific ERISA and Internal Revenue Code sections. The employer's liability for a terminated pension plan under the Security Act of 1974 is determined based on specific assumptions and methods. This liability replaces any other obligations to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. If an eligible employer does not elect spinoff, they are liable for the terminated plan under ERISA. If an eligible employer does not elect spinoff, they are liable for the terminated pension plan under ERISA, in an amount equal to the fractional portion of the adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities of the plan. The employer is liable for the pension plan's unfunded benefit liabilities if they do not elect spinoff. Adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities are determined as of December 31, 2005. Adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities are the amount of unfunded benefit liabilities with a specific interest assumption. The term "fractional portion" refers to a fraction representing the amount required to be contributed to the pension plan for the 5 plan years before. The term "fractional portion" is defined as a fraction where the numerator is the amount required to be contributed to the pension plan by the employer for the 5 plan years before December 31, 2005, and the denominator is the total amount required to be contributed by all employers who do not make a specific election. The term "applicable pension plan" refers to a single employer plan established in Alaska on March 18, 1967, with 2 or more contributing sponsors, at least 2 of which are not under common control. The term "allocable portion" is defined as the portion eligible employers contribute when making an election. The term "allocable portion" refers to the portion of an applicable pension plan's liabilities and assets that eligible employers contribute when making an election. The excess of plan liabilities over plan assets, determined for eligible employers in an eligible multiple employer plan, is divided by the total excess amount to calculate the allocable portion. An eligible employer is defined as one participating in the plan after January 1, 2000.
